Congratulations to Dan Zaleski, a fifth-grade teacher Hurricane Elementary School, who is first and foremost an advocate for his students. He works to have a personal relationship with them so they can succeed. Along with teaching fifth grade, Zalenski is a partner teacher in the Spanish Dual Immersion Program. A parent wrote, “my daughter used to hate math and considered it her worst subject…It was too hard. After Mr. Zaleski taught her and convinced her that ‘math always makes sense and has patterns’ she learned to understand how math works…Now she loves math and it is her favorite subject.”

With more than 33 years in the classroom, Mr Zalenski has impacted multiple generations of students. A colleague writes, “Not only has he taught the children of former students, he is now teaching the next generation of grandchildren of his former students. Over twenty of his former students have become teachers themselves, and two are now college professors due in part to Dan's influence.”

https://www.pbsutah.org/uea-excellence-teaching-awards/2020#Dan

Some great news out of Fossil Ridge Intermediate!

Fossil Ridge Intermediate has two students who placed in the top 20 of the state’s "Do the Write Thing" essay challenge:

Elissa Petrell and Henry Heaton!

This challenge is a national and state focus on ending youth violence. The students wrote essays describing how violence impacts lives and how it can be stopped, focusing on a strong, personal voice and empowering youth. Both students were recognized in a statewide recognition ceremony and will receive a certificate with Governor Herbert’s signature.

Congratulations, Henry and Elissa!

(Photos shared with parent permission)

Also from Fossil Ridge

Two Fossil Ridge students placed 2nd and 3rd in the local "Elks Lodge patriotic essay" contest this year:

Maraya Sanchez and Jordyn Andrew!

The topic was What does freedom of speech mean to me? and was judged on how well the students expressed feelings and ideas about the First Amendment.

Maraya also placed 2nd in the state essay contest.

Congratulations, Maraya and Jordyn!

(Photos shared with parent permission)

Janet Morwood’s name certainly fits this beloved 1st grade teacher of 40 years at Santa Clara Elementary. She is MORE…

More dedicated, more kind, and more unruffled than you can imagine. After being in the same classroom, same grade, and same school for over 40 years, she knows 6 and 7-year-olds very well! She is an amazing reading teacher. Consistently, almost all of her students reach benchmark by the end of the year. She has a way of getting her students to not just read, but to love reading! Her class is the top reading class for number of books read in the library year after year. She has loved and nurtured some of the most energetic students that have gone through our school. She has been, and continues to be, a mentor and friend to teachers both new and old. With a warm smile, a contagious laugh over 1st grade classroom antics, and a loving heart, Janet Morwood has been a blessing to hundreds of 1st grade students these past 40 years. Here’s to “more” yet to come.

#WashK12Difference #TeachandLive #BetterDownSouth #SupportingTeachers

post_text: We are always impressed with the great kids we have here in WCSD. “A single act of kindness throws out roots in all directions, and the roots spring up and make new trees.” - Amelia Earhart
shared_text:
Mitzi Kelly Sampson
September 16, 2019 at 1:03 AM ·

DHHS way to go! With so much bad publicity in the news about DHHS I thought I would show you the good. Last Tuesday while most students were finding dates or trying on dresses for Homecoming, one special group entered the Severe Special Ed class room and asked the entire class to go to Homecoming with them.

As nice as that gesture is, these students didn’t have a clue just how profound their kindness was. As a mom with a daughter of special needs, long ago I was taught to mourn the dreams I had for my daughter, but also to create new ones that were achievable for her. There would be no homecoming, there would be no dresses, no close friends, no college, no first kisses.

Last night one of those moments I thought she would never experience became a reality. My daughter was so excited to dress up, have her nails and hair done and to be apart of something fun with other students. This happened because of some great students at DHHS.

Thank you to those who thought outside the box, put others who aren’t exactly like them first, and showed them real love.

A lot of people are struggling, that’s OK. If you are struggling, don’t be afraid to seek help. Talk to a teacher. We love and care about you. We are grateful to Dan Reynolds & Imagine Dragons for allowing us to share this message. #SuicidePrevention Safe_UT #WashK12Difference

(Back story): We had the opportunity to see Imagine Dragons live when Dan Reynolds paused his song to speak to the audience about depression, anxiety and having a therapist. For the past couple of weeks, we (Washington County School District) have been seeking permission from Dan and Imagine Dragons to share this message with the children in our school district. Yesterday we got word..."Permission Granted!"

So many children and adults around us struggle with depression and anxiety. It's something Washington County School District is trying to put more of a focus on. It's something we should all talk about.

We are pleased to announce the selection of Amy Mitchell as the new Title 1 Program Director. Amy will replace Kathy Peterson who will retire at the end of this contract year.

This is Amy's 24th year serving in the Washington County School District. She has worked in numerous schools as a teacher, Learning Coach, and Reading Recovery Teacher Leader. For the past five years, she has been the Principal of Red Mountain Elementary School. Amy treasures the many friendships she has around the district, and will deeply miss her Red Mountain family.

Amy attended university at BYU, SUU, and SDSU, completing her Master of Education degree, reading endorsements, and Elementary, Early Childhood, and Administrative Licenses. While she cherishes her many educational experiences, one of the highlights of her career was lobbying on Capitol Hill to promote early reading interventions. Just as her predecessor, Kathy Petersen has done, she will dedicate her time as Title I Director to helping at-risk students learn at high levels.

Please join with us in welcoming Amy Mitchell to her new assignment.

Parents,

Here’s a great tool to help your child find success in education! When your child takes the SAGE test their scores can be entered into our new ACT Estimator. This can help predict how they will do later when they take the ACT test.

By taking the SAGE test, and continuing to take it each year, students can know what skills and concepts they need to focus on to be successful later on the ACT. In addition, because we do not use the SAGE test as part of a student’s grade, it allows the child to practice taking a high-stakes test, in a low-pressure environment. This is teaching your student important test-taking skills, ensuring knowledge of key standards and preparing them for the actual ACT test in the 11th grade.

Watch this brief video then click on our ACT Estimator link.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dw3Lfjalvmw&feature=youtu.be

Link to the ACT Estimator: http://assessment.washk12.org/act-estimator

The Board is pleased to announce the in-district transfer selection of Brian Stevenson as the Principal of Crimson Cliffs Middle School, scheduled to open in August of 2018. Crimson Cliffs Middle School is located south of the Treasure Valley Sub Division in Washington (south of 4200 South).

Brian has served in the Washington County School District for the past 21 years. He graduated from Southern Utah University with a degree in Biological Science and Secondary Education. In 1996 he accepted his first teaching assignment as a science teacher at Pine View Middle School.

In 2002, after receiving a Masters Degree in Educational Leadership from Southern Utah University, Brian accepted a position as the assistant principal and athletic director at Snow Canyon High School. In 2007, Brian opened Desert Hills Middle School where he has served as the principal for the past ten years. Brian has loved working with the great community, faculty, staff, and students at Desert Hills Middle School.

Tonaquint Intermediate received their 3rd re-designation Schools to Watch Award at the June conference in Washington DC. The National Forum identifies schools across the United States that are well on their way to meeting the Forum’s criteria for high performance. There are only 10 schools in the state of Utah which meet these rigorous criteria.

To be nationally recognized as a Schools to Watch, schools must demonstrate:

• They are academically excellent — these schools challenge all students to use their minds well.
• They are developmentally responsive — these schools are sensitive to the unique developmental challenges of early adolescence.
• They are socially equitable — these schools are democratic and fair, providing every student with high-quality teachers, resources, and supports.

To achieve this level of performance, high-performing schools establish norms, structures, and organizational arrangements to support and sustain their trajectory toward excellence. They have a sense of purpose that drives every facet of practice and decision-making.
